theme.title: Terminal cadences
theme.para: Terminal cadences create a sensation of stability and conclusion of the musical phrase or sentence. This feeling is achieved by moving to the tonic grade (grade I) from any other chord grade. Depending on the starting chord grade, two types of cadences are considered: authentic cadences and plagal cadences.

part.title: Authentic cadences
part.para: An authentic cadence takes place when grade V, dominant, (or V7, a V chord with an added seventh) resolves in grade I (tonic). The authentic cadence is the strongest terminal cadence, with great conclusive power.

part.para: When the authentic cadence satisfies the following conditions:

orderedlist.listitem: both chords are in root position;
the first chord is the V or the V7 ; and
the melody (soprano voice) ends on the tonic pitch.

part.para: then the cadence has its strongest conclusive power and it creates the most final sounding of all cadences. Due to this fact, if the previously listed conditions are satisfied, the cadence is named 'perfect authentic cadence' or just 'perfect cadence'. If the conditions are not satisfied, the conclusive sensation of the cadence is less strong and then the cadence is named 'imperfect authentic cadence' or just 'imperfect cadence'.
There are theoretical discussions about considering the imperfect cadence as a terminal cadence. Nevertheless, we have opted to include it in the terminal group due to sonority considerations.
The perfect cadence is usually found at the end of a piece of music and the end of significant sections.

part.title: Plagal cadences
part.para: A plagal cadence takes place when grade IV (subdominant) resolves in grade I (tonic), both in root position. The plagal cadence is less strong than the authentic cadence and it is also known as the 'Amen' cadence as it is used at the end of most church hymns.

In both cadence types, authentic and plagal, other chords playing the same harmonic functions can be used. For example, in the authentic cadence the V (dominant function) can be played by the VII. And in the plagal cadence the IV (subdominant function) can be played by the II. These replacements add variety and harmonic colour to the cadence.

part.title: Exercises
part.para: Aural training - Train your ear and practise to identify if a terminal cadence is authentic perfect or plagal.
Theory - Practise to recognize in a score if a terminal cadence is authentic perfect or plagal.
